content.text:
<image 1> Suppose the government decided that, since gasoline is a necessity, its price should be legally capped at $1.30 per gallon. What do you anticipate would be the outcome in the gasoline market?

A. A price below that of 1.30 dollars would cause a situation of excess demand and hence a surplus.
B. A price below that of 1.30 dollars would cause a situation of excess demand and hence a shortage.
C. Not certain.

B. A price below that of 1.30 dollars would cause a situation of excess demand and hence a shortage.

When the government legally caps the price of gasoline at $1.30 per gallon, it is below the equilibrium price of $1.40 per gallon. At this lower price, the quantity demanded will be greater than the quantity supplied, leading to a situation of excess demand or shortage. This means that there will be a shortage of gasoline because the quantity that consumers want to buy at the capped price exceeds the quantity that producers are willing to supply at that price.
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
